journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: An experimental study on spray characteristics after impingement on a piston surface through an asymmetrical multi-hole injector of a direct-injection spark ignition gasoline engine

article-meta.aff: School of Automotive Studies, Tongji University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *School of Automotive Studies, Tongji University, Shanghai 200092, People’s Republic of China. email: liguang@tongji.edu.cn

abstract.p: The impinging spray development inside direct-injection spark ignition (DISI) engines directly influences the engine performance and emissions. A detailed understanding of this process is very important in designing an injection system and controlling a strategy. To examine the effects of various factors on the development of a spray impinging on the piston top surface, experiments were conducted under various injection pressures, ambient pressures, and piston top surface shapes inside an optical constant-volume chamber employing a high-speed shadow photography technique. Also, the effects of the injection pressure, ambient pressure, and piston top surface shape on the impinging spray concentration, impinging spray tip penetration, impinging spray radius, impinging spray height, and impinging spray tip speed were analysed. It is shown that atomization after the spray had impinged on the piston top surface became increasingly better as the injection pressure increased. The concentration of the spray plumes before and after the spray had impinged on the piston top surface became increasingly richer as the ambient pressure increased. The impinging spray tip penetration and radius increased with increasing injection pressure, but the impinging spray tip penetration and radius decreased with increasing ambient pressure. This investigation is favourable to providing further basic data for the impinging spray history and the mixture preparation of DISI engines.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Direct-injection spark ignition (DISI) engines have the potential to reduce fuel consumption markedly and to improve the engine performance [1]. Also, the impingement of fuel spray on to interposed surfaces in a direct-injection engine is a fundamental issue affecting mixture preparation prior to combustion and also affecting the engine performance and pollutant emissions [2]. The impingement of a fuel spray on the surface of the piston cavity is intentionally utilized to establish a stratified-charge mixture in wall-guided gasoline direct-injection (GDI) combustion systems but, for this system, for spray-guided and air-guided systems, and for homogeneous-charge operation, some degree of unintended spray–wall impingement on the piston and cylinder surface is inevitable. With such spray–wall impingement expected, an improved understanding of the spray–wall impingement process is extremely important in the DISI engine development process either to utilize the intentional spray–wall impingement better in the wall-guided concept or to adjust the parameters to avoid unintended spray–wall wetting. Some experimental and numerical investigations have been conducted with a goal of understanding the spray–wall impingement development in DISI engines.

Two-dimensional pulse-laser Mie scattering visualization of the GDI fuel sprays and wall impingement process was performed inside a single-cylinder, optically accessible engine under motoring conditions. The results showed that the extent of wall impingement varied significantly with the injector mounting position and the spray cone angle; however, its effect can be reduced to some extent by optimizing the injection timing [3].

The GDI spray–wall interaction was investigated inside a heated pressurized chamber using various visualization techniques. The results showed that the upward spray vortex inside the spray was more obvious in high-temperature conditions and that more rapid impingement and faster horizontal spread after impingement were observed under high-temperature conditions [4].

Current spray–wall impingement models were reviewed and a sensitive analysis of a common spray impingement model was performed. It was found that models based on single-droplet experiments were insufficient to calculate the spray–wall impingement process. Also, the results on the tangential velocity obtained after spray–wall impingement were smaller than the experimental results [5].

The interaction between the spray tip penetration and the piston trajectory for both late- and early-injection regimes were considered to minimize the fuel impingement in the DISI engine design stage [6].
In addition, many investigations have shown that the fuel impingement of large droplets on the piston crown was one of the major sources of hydrocarbon (HC) and particulate emissions [7–9].

Previous investigations mostly focused on the spray–wall impingement processes in diesel engines [10, 11], port fuel injection engines [12], and a DISI engine with a low injection pressure. The purpose of this study was to investigate the effects of such different boundary conditions as the injection pressure (6 MPa, 9 MPa, and 12 MPa), the ambient pressure (0.1 MPa, 0.6 MPa, and 1.1 MPa), and the piston top shape on the spray–wall impingement history in detail, using an optical constant-volume bomb and high-speed shadow photography technique. In addition, the effects of different boundary parameters on the fuel concentration of the spray plume were analysed using a self-compiling program. The investigations could provide basic data for optimizing the fuel injection system and combustion chamber and can guide the combustion and emission optimization of DISI gasoline engines.

sec.title: 2.1 Spray visualization testing rig
sec.p: The testing rig of the spray–wall impingement process is depicted in Fig. 1, which is composed of a constant-volume chamber, a fuel-supply system, the direct-injection injector with six nozzle holes (five holes of 57° angle and one hole of 75° angle) shown in Fig. 2, and a high-speed camera used to photograph the spray–wall impingement process. The constant-volume chamber can be pressurized up to 5 MPa with nitrogen (N2) gas.

caption.p: Impinging spray testing rig: 1, computer; 2, high-speed camera; 3, halogen lamp; 4, optical chamber; 5, 8, gas-pressure meters; 6, 7, nitrogen cylinders; 9, high-pressure fuel-supply system; 10, tank; 11, gasoline filter; 12, electronic control unit (ECU); 13, oil-pressure transducer
Scheme of the nozzle structure

sec.p: The gasoline fuel is supplied under constant pressure from an accumulator pressurized with N2 gas. The accumulator made of stainless steel supplies the high-pressure fuel up to about 25 MPa.

The key component of the experimental set-up for this study is a piston installation inside the optical constant-volume chamber. A support designed by the present authors is applied in order to fix the piston.

In addition, the frame rate of the high-speed camera was maintained at 25 000 frames/s in the experiment. The specifications of the high-speed camera and the injector used for the GDI are shown in Table 1.

caption.p: Specifications for the high-speed camera and the injector for GDI

sec.title: 2.2 Experimental schemes
sec.p: To clarify the effect of the boundary conditions on the spray–wall impingement, the experiments have been carried out under various boundary conditions. The detailed experimental schemes are listed in Table 2.

caption.p: Experimental schemes

sec.title: 2.3 Piston top shape and parameter definition
sec.p: Two pistons were selected in order to study the effects of the piston top shape on the spray–wall impingement history, as depicted schematically in Fig. 3.

caption.p: Piston top shape: (a) top view of piston A; (b) side view of piston A; (c) top view of piston B and (d) side view of piston B

sec.p: In addition, the free spray, the impinging spray, the spray impinging angle, and the spray impinging distance are defined as follows.

list-item.p: The free spray was defined as the spray before it had impinged on to the piston.
The impinging spray was defined as the spray after it had impinged on to the piston.
The spray impinging angle α was defined as the included angle between the spray axis and the piston top level, as shown in Fig. 4.
The spray impinging distance D was defined as the vertical distance from the injector nozzle to the location of the piston bowl.

caption.p: Impinging angle

sec.p: To explain the impinging spray history through an asymmetrical multi-hole injector of a DISI gasoline engine, some parameters were presented as follows.

list-item.p: The impinging spray radius R1 was defined as the distance from the axis of the injector to the left end of the impinging spray, as shown in Fig. 5.
The impinging spray radius R2 was defined as the distance from the axis of the injector to the right end of the impinging spray, as shown in Fig. 5.
The impinging spray height H1 was defined as the distance from the bottom to the top of the left spray after it had impinged on to the piston top surface, as shown in Fig. 5.
The impinging spray height H2 was defined as the distance from the bottom to the top of the right spray after it had impinged on to the piston top surface, as shown in Fig. 5.
The impinging spray tip penetration was defined as [13, 14]
Based on the above equation, excluding the impinging distance D, L1 is the left impinging spray tip penetration (the exhaust valve side) given by
and L2 is the right impinging spray tip penetration (the intake valve side) given by

The impinging spray tip speed was calculated from the increment in the spray path penetrations obtained from sequential images. V1 is the speed of the left spray after it had impinged on to the piston top surface, and V2 is the speed of the right spray after it had impinged on to the piston top surface.

caption.p: Impinging spray parameter

sec.p: In addition, the definitions of the impinging spray parameters for piston B are the same as those for piston A.

sec.title: 3.1 Effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray characteristics
sec.p: In the case of early injection, the injection timing was selected such that the fuel spray does not impinge on the piston top surface to avoid surface wetting. When this requirement is satisfied, earlier injection timing is preferable so as to promote evaporation and mixing of the fuel [6]. The higher the injection pressure, the better is the spray atomization, but the longer is the spray tip penetration, resulting in easier spray impingement on to the piston top surface and cylinder liner. In order to study the effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray characteristics, the impinging spray history, the concentration change of the impinging spray, the impinging spray tip penetration, the impinging spray radius, the impinging spray height, and the impinging spray tip speed for piston A under injection pressures of 6 MPa, 9 MPa, and 12 MPa, an ambient pressure of 0.1 MPa (corresponding to early injection), an ambient temperature of 25 °C, an impinging distance of 26.1 mm, and an impinging angle of 75° are illustrated in Fig. 6, Fig. 7, Fig. 8, Fig. 9, and Fig. 10 respectively.

caption.p: Effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray history
Effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray tip penetration
Effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray radius
Effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray height
Effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray tip speed

sec.p: Figure 6 shows the effects of the injection pressure on the impinging spray history and the concentration change after the spray had impinged on to the piston top surface. It can be seen that the amounts of the impinging spray increased, mainly because the spray tip penetration increased as the fuel injection pressure increased. The fuel injection pressure had only a slight effect on the upward vortices generated after the spray had impinged on the piston top surface. The fuel atomization after spray had impinged on to the piston top surface was improved slightly, owing to the decrease in the fuel droplet size. Also, the concentration of the spray after it had impinged on to the piston top surface became accordingly diluted as the fuel injection pressure increased. It can also be seen that the liquid film seems to become lean when the fuel injection pressure increased, owing mainly to the improvement in spray atomization. In other words, because the clearance height is generally quite small for earlier- or later-injection DISI engines, the fuel spray from the DISI injectors having high penetration rates could result in some degree of unintended wall impingement. The fuel injection pressure should be determined on the basis of the injection timing and the working conditions, and to the greatest extent avoiding unintended spray–wall impingement.

Figure 7 shows the effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray tip penetration. It can be seen that the free spray increased but, after it had impinged on to the piston top surface, the impinging spray tip penetrations decreased first and increased subsequently with increasing injection pressure. The former arises because the higher injection pressure improves spray atomization; the latter is due to the increase in the initial spray speed. The increase in the injection pressure has little effect on the time when the spray impinges on to the piston top surface. Also, on comparing the spray tip penetration before and after the spray had impinged on to the piston top surface, it can be seen that the slope of the curve decreased but that the elevated injection pressure improved the rising rate of the impinging spray tip penetration. The results on the impinging spray tip penetration are different from those of the reference (an injection distance of 30 mm, an ambient pressure of 0.5 MPa, and an ambient temperature of 373 K [14]) which increased with increasing injection pressure, because the higher temperature and ambient pressure conceal the effect of the higher injection pressure on initial spray atomization.

Figure 8 shows the effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray radius. It can also be seen that the impinging spray radius in the early period decreased but increased in the late period with increasing injection pressure. In the investigation, the larger impinging spray radius R1 caused the spray to impinge secondarily on the cylinder liner of the exhaust valve side; also the larger impinging spray radius R2 increased the probability that the spray impinged secondarily on the cylinder liner of the intake valve side. The asymmetric nozzle hole resulted in a left impinging spray radius that was larger than the right impinging spray radius.

Figure 9 shows the effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray height. It can be seen that the impinging spray height increased with increasing injection pressure. Also, the larger impinging spray height induced the spray to impinge on the chamber top, when the fuel is injected during the late period of the compression stroke. However, the appropriate impinging spray height has an important effect on the stratified charge at the spark plug. In addition, the left impinging spray height is larger than the right impinging spray height owing to the piston top shape and asymmetric nozzle structure.

Figure 10 shows the effect of the injection pressure on the impinging spray tip speed. It can be seen that the impinging spray tip speed increased with increasing injection pressure. The free-spray tip speed decreases rapidly after impingement of the spray; this suggested that, because the spray impinges on to the piston top surface, this resulted in velocity deceleration at the impingement point.

sec.title: 3.2 Effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray characteristics
sec.p: As the ambient pressure increases, the spray atomization becomes worse. Therefore the ambient pressure has an important effect on the impinging spray. The impinging spray history, the concentration change of impinging spray, the impinging spray tip penetration, the impinging spray radius, the impinging spray height, and the impinging spray tip speed for piston A under an injection pressure of 9 MPa, ambient pressures of 0.1 MPa, 0.6 MPa, and 1.1 MPa, an ambient temperature of 25 °C, an impinging distance of 26.1 mm, and an impinging angle of 75° are illustrated in Fig. 11, Fig. 12, Fig. 13, Fig. 14, and Fig. 15 respectively.

caption.p: Effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray history
Effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray tip penetration
Effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray radius
Effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray height
Effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray tip speed

sec.p: Figure 11 shows the effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray history and the concentration change after the spray had impinged on to the piston top surface. It can be seen that the elevated ambient pressure resulted in an increase in the amount of impinging spray; this is because the spray atomization degraded before the spray had impinged on to the piston top surface. In addition, the fuel concentration of the spray plume became increasingly richer with increasing ambient pressure. It can also be seen that the liquid film forming on the piston top surface gradually thickened as the ambient pressure increased; this is mainly because the higher ambient pressure resulted in the larger droplets. Based on the investigations by Iiyama et al. [15], the level of soot emissions is more dependent on the wall film thickness and less related to the total amount of fuel on the piston top surface. It can be concluded that the higher ambient pressure could result in an increase in the film thickness on the piston top surface, further inducing an increase in the engine-out soot emissions. It should be especially noted that a fuel late-injection event occurs during the compression stroke.

Figure 12 shows the effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray tip penetration. It can be seen that the time of spray–wall impingement was delayed as the ambient pressure increased, owing mainly to an increase in the ambient pressure which resulted in a decrease in the spray tip speed. The impinging spray tip penetration decreased as the ambient pressure increased; this trend is the same as the results of the slit-type GDI injector at an injection pressure of 12 MPa and an impinging angle of 90° [14], mainly because the higher ambient pressure results in an increase in the surrounding gas density, which increases the drag force acting on the development of fuel droplets. The left and right spray tip penetrations under the 0.1 MPa ambient pressure condition are on average about 7.7 mm and 1.8 mm respectively larger than under the 0.6 MPa ambient pressure condition.

In addition, all the impinging sprays grew more rapidly in the lower-ambient-pressure condition. The slope after impingement was steeper with decreasing ambient pressure. It seems that the droplets have more momentum owing to the lower ambient pressure, resulting in greater energy transfer during rebound. This resulted in a steeper slope than for the other impingement sprays [14].

Figure 13 shows the effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray radius. It can be seen that the impinging spray radius decreased as the ambient pressure increased. In contrast with the injection pressure, the ambient pressure has a more important effect on the impinging spray radius. The elevated ambient pressure reduced the probability that the spray impinged secondarily on the cylinder liner. The left and right spray radii under the 0.1 MPa ambient pressure condition are on average about 6.8 mm and 1.6 mm respectively larger than that under the 0.6 MPa ambient pressure condition, and on average about 9.8 mm and 2.7 mm respectively larger than those under the 1.1 MPa ambient pressure condition.

Figure 14 shows the effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray height. It can be seen that the impinging spray height decreased as the ambient pressure increased, because the higher ambient pressure results in an increase in the gas density, which causes impinging spray diffusion.

Figure 15 shows the effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray tip speed. It can be seen that the impinging spray tip speed decreased as the ambient pressure increased, because the higher ambient pressure results in an increase in the gas density, and consequently an increase in the resistance. The trends of the left and right impinging spray tip speeds for the GDI multi-hole injector under different ambient pressures are the same as those in a GDI high-pressure swirl injector [16].

sec.title: 3.3 Effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray characteristics
sec.p: The effects of the piston top shape on the impinging spray history, the concentration of impinging spray, the impinging spray tip penetration, the impinging spray radius, the impinging spray height, and the impinging spray tip speed under an injection pressure of 9 MPa, an ambient pressure of 0.1 MPa, an ambient temperature of 25 °C, an impinging distance of 26.1 mm, and an impinging angle of 75° are presented in Fig. 16, Fig. 17, Fig. 18, Fig. 19, and Fig. 20 respectively.

caption.p: Effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray history
Effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray tip penetration
Effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray radius
Effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray height
Effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray tip speed

sec.p: Figure 16 shows the effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray history and the concentration change after spray had impinged on to piston top surface. Many investigations have shown that the piston top shape is a key factor in the in-cylinder mixture formation in DISI gasoline engines [17]. It can be seen from Fig. 16 that the upward spray vortex inside the left spray for piston A was more obvious, and more rapid downward and horizontal spread after impingement was observed for piston B. Thus piston B seems to be unfavourable to the impinging spray history and fuel atomization, resulting in more fuel impingement on to the left side of the optical chamber. However, piston A is favourable to the appropriate mixture formation in the vicinity of the spark plug. When the spray impinges on to the cylinder liner of the exhaust port side, the engine-out HC emissions generated are twice those impinging on to the intake port side, and more than those impinging on to the piston top [18]. Therefore, it could be concluded that piston A seems to be favourable to an injector with an asymmetric nozzle-hole arrangement, avoiding fuel impingement on to the cylinder liner, and further favourable to reducing engine-out HC emissions. In addition, on the one hand, based on the unburned HC formation mechanism [1, 19], if much spray impinges on to the cylinder liner, the cylinder wall wetting results in an increase in unburned HC emission. On the other hand, the top-ring-land crevice is not a significant light-load HC source in this DISI engine, because gases trapped in the crevice contain relatively little fuel in charge stratification mode [20], but, when the fuel impinging on to the cylinder liner does not evaporate in time, the fuel enters into the top-ring-land crevice with the piston moving upwards and subsequently is released from the crevice in the expansion stroke. Hence it was speculated that avoiding fuel impingement on to the cylinder liner is favourable to reducing the generation of engine-out HC emissions.

Figure 17 shows the effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray tip penetration. It can be seen that the left impinging spray tip penetration for piston A is smaller than that for piston B; for the right impinging spray tip penetration, the converse is true. This is because the piston cavity changes the direction of spray motion after the spray had impinged on to the piston top surface, but the difference from the right impinging spray is small because the right piston top structure is similar. The left and right spray tip penetrations of piston A are on average about 16 mm smaller and 1.2 mm larger respectively than those of piston B.

Figure 18 shows the effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray radius. It can be seen that the left impinging spray radius for piston A is on average about 8.4 mm smaller than that for piston B, but the right impinging spray radius for piston A is on average about 1.4 mm larger than that for piston B. It can be concluded that piston B more easily induced the impinging spray to impinge secondarily on to the cylinder liner, when the fuel is injected at the early or late period of the intake or compression stroke.

Figure 19 shows the effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray height. It can be seen that the left impinging spray height for piston A is on average about 2.1 mm larger than that for piston B, and the right impinging spray height for piston A is on average about 0.23 mm larger than that for piston B. It can be concluded that piston A is more useful to the stratified charge at the spark plug, but it can also result in an increased probability that the spray impinges on the chamber top.

Figure 20 shows the effect of the piston top shape on the impinging spray tip speed under an injection pressure of 9 MPa, an ambient pressure of 0.1 MPa, an ambient temperature of 25 °C, an impinging distance of 26.1 mm, and an impinging angle of 75°. It can be seen that the left impinging spray tip speed for piston A is smaller than that for piston B; this is because the piston cavity changes the direction of spray motion after the spray had impinged on to the piston top surface.

sec.title: 3.4 Discussion
sec.p: Although many impinging spray experiments have been conducted for diesel and GDI injectors, generally, a plain plate was selected as an impact wall [13, 14], and a single side impinging spray tip penetration, impinging spray radius, and impinging spray height were calculated in the previous investigations, but, in the investigations, the data for the intake side and the exhaust side were calculated separately in order to characterize the impinging spray of an asymmetric multi-hole injector.

All results in the impinging spray experiment were obtained without consideration of the flow motion, the piston movement, and the variation in the piston surface temperature, because of the restriction of experimental conditions. The above conditions have an important effect on the spray–wall interaction, to some extent; there are some discrepancies between the results with and without these conditions; hence, to characterize the impinging spray exactly in the real engine, these factors should be considered in future investigations.

However, this study of an impinging spray in the cold optical constant-volume chamber has great significance in optimizing the operating parameters (the injection pressure) and matching the piston top shape with the injector in order to form a stratified or homogeneous mixture. Studying the results gives some general guides on the optimization and design of a GDI engine as follows: it provides basic data for the selection of the injection pressure and the injection timing in different operation conditions; it indicates that the impinging spray radius and the height are also important to mixture formation; it presents the right and left separate spray tip penetrations, spray height, and spray radius after the spray had impinged on to the piston top surface in order to be favourable for characterizing the impinging spray history; it demonstrates that the piston top shape is a key parameter in the impinging spray development; it shows that the piston design for forming a proper mixture is favourable to stratified mixture formation.

sec.title: 4 Conclusions
sec.p: The results obtained from the impinging spray experiment can be summarized as follows.

list-item.p: The impinging spray penetration, impinging spray radius, impinging spray height, and impinging spray tip speed increased with increasing injection pressure. Also, the concentration of the spray after it had impinged on to piston top surface became increasingly leaner.

The impinging spray tip penetration, impinging spray radius, impinging spray height, and impinging spray tip speed decreased with increasing ambient pressure. After impingement, the left and right spray tip penetrations under the 0.1 MPa ambient pressure condition are on average about 7.7 mm and 1.8 mm respectively larger than those under the 0.6 MPa ambient pressure condition. In addition, the effect of the ambient pressure on the impinging spray is more important than that of the injection pressure.

The left and right spray tip penetrations of piston A are on average about 16 mm smaller and 1.2 mm larger respectively than those of piston B. The left and right impinging spray radius for piston A are on average about 8.4 mm smaller and 1.4 mm larger respectively than those for piston B. It could be concluded that piston A seems to be favourable to forming the appropriate mixture in the vicinity of the spark plug in a wall-guided stratified-charge direct-injection engine.

Based on the investigation, it is suggested that, when the fuel is directly injected into the chamber in the intake stroke for a DISI engine with a homogeneous mixture and in the compression stroke for a spray-guided DISI engine, a lower injection pressure and a higher injection pressure respectively should be selected. When the impingement of the fuel spray is required in the wall-guided stratified-charge combustion mode, an appropriately deeper piston bowl should be designed, which is equipped with a GDI injector. In addition, the fuel film and air motion in the DISI engine play important roles in the spray impingement process, and so these factors should be considered in future studies.
